Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Deleted User https://github.com/leto/address-validator

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: FYI BTC addresses also have checksum'ing but it's not commonly checked by applications: https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Base58Check_encoding

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ```(Beware of bignumber implementations that clip leading 0x00 bytes, or prepend extra 0x00 bytes to indicate sign - your code must handle these cases properly or else you may generate valid-looking addresses which can be sent to, but cannot be spent from - which would lead to the permanent loss of coins.)```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: seems that even btc core allows sending to invalid checksum addresses but they can't be spent from. ouch.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: addresses dont exist on the blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think it issue is if the rmd160 hash has leading base58 nulls and they are suppressed, it ends up being a different hash value that is encoded in the address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all address checksums are validated in the bitcoin code that sends to addresses (that I have seen)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that wiki may be quite old and wrong, i believe James and yes, addresses don't exist on the blockchain. Still learning that lesson....

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Thing I learned today: Sapling addresses are actually bech32 format, not base58, which made me realize how to make the last failing tests pass üòÉ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: in practice, this means that Sapling zaddrs contain only a-z0-9 chars, while taddrs also contain uppercase (except for O, I), and don't include "l" or zero

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's invalid for them to have mixed case
